Welcome to Platformer’s documentation!¶

Platformer main script¶

The platformer module: contains the initialization of the main game objects and the game loop.

Run platformer.py script to start the game!

Platformer world¶

The world module: contains World class, which is responsible for displaying game objects on the screen.

class world.World(data, blob_group, lava_group, exit_group, coin_group, platform_group)[source]¶

A class used to represent the world

Attributes:
datatwo-dimensional array

represent the world

worldclass World

the world in which you want to draw the player

blob_group : pygame.sprite.Group()

lava_group : pygame.sprite.Group()

exit_group : pygame.sprite.Group()

coin_group : pygame.sprite.Group()

platform_group : pygame.sprite.Group()

draw()[source]¶

Fill the world with elementary blocks

make_world()[source]¶

Parsing a two-dimensional array and filling in sprite groups

Platformer enemies¶

The enemies module: contains objects that the game reloads when interacting with.

class enemies.Enemy(x, y)[source]¶

A class used to represent the blob

Attributes:
xfloat

x coordinate

yfloat

y coordinate

update()[source]¶

Allows the enemy to move left and right

class enemies.Lava(x, y)[source]¶

A class used to represent the lava the built-in update method is used

Attributes:
xfloat

x coordinate

yfloat

y coordinate

Platformer player¶

The player module: contains the main event handling from the user’s keyboard.

A class used to represent the player

yfloat

y coordinate

the world in which you want to draw the player

lava_group : pygame.sprite.Group()

exit_group : pygame.sprite.Group()

change_world(new_world)[source]¶

Change world for player

Args:

new_world(two-dimensional array)

Returns:

None

reset(x, y)[source]¶

Reset player’s condition Moves the player’s sprite to the starting position and resets the effects

Args:
xfloat

new x position

yfloat

new y position

Returns:

None

update(game_over, score, game_completed, sounds)[source]¶

Updates the state on each frame of the player: tracks movement and collision with objects

Args:
game_overbool

flag for determining the progress status of the game

scoreint

Uses the current score counter

game_complitedbool

flag for determining the victory in the game

soundsdict[str, fx]

dictionary with sounds for different situations

Returns:

new conditions of game_over and score

Platformer world environment¶

The world_environment module: contains static game objects that the player can interact with.

class world_environment.Background(*args)[source]¶

A class used to represent the world

Attributes:
*args*(name strings of pictures(str), (xcoord(int), ycoord(int)))

arguments are served in the order they are added to the background screen

draw()[source]¶

Draws background images

class world_environment.Button(x, y, image_name)[source]¶

A class used to represent buttons

Attributes:
xfloat

x coordinate

yfloat

y coordinate

image_namestr

the name of the image that represents the button

draw()[source]¶

draws the button image to the screen and tracks the mouse click on each frame

class world_environment.Coin(x, y)[source]¶

A class used to represent coins the built-in update method is used

yfloat

A class used to represent exit doors the built-in update method is used

yfloat

class world_environment.Platform(x, y, move_x, move_y)[source]¶

A class used to represent moving platforms the built-in update method is used

Attributes:
xfloat

x coordinate

yfloat

y coordinate

move_xfloat

speed on the x-axis

move_yfloat

speed on the y-axis

update()[source]¶

method to control sprite behavior

Sprite.update(*args, **kwargs):

The default implementation of this method does nothing; it’s just a convenient “hook” that you can override. This method is called by Group.update() with whatever arguments you give it.

There is no need to use this method if not using the convenience method by the same name in the Group class.

Platformer constants¶

The constants module: contains global variables and game settings:

Options:

fps(int) - fps option

screen_width(int) - width of the screen

screen_height(int) - height of the screen

screen(pygame.display) - game screen from the pygame module

tile_size(int) - size of the elementary screen block for filling the world with objects

level(int) - current level of game

max_levels(int) - number of levels to complete the game

sound_volume(float) - soun volume from 0 to 1

Platformer functions¶

The function module: contains the necessary functions for working with the World class and displaying text on the screen

functions.draw_text(text, font, text_col, x, y)[source]¶

Draws text to the screen when the function is called

Args:

text (str): Output text

font (pygame.font): Font for text

text_col (tuple[Literal[255], Literal[255], Literal[255]]): RGB color

x (float): x coordinate

y (float): y coordinate

Returns:

None

functions.load_world(level, stage)[source]¶

Pulls data from a json file and returns it as a two-dimensional array

Args:

level(int): level of stage to be load stage(int): game’s stage number

Returns:

two-dimensional array with representation of the world

functions.reset_level(level, player, blob_group, lava_group, exit_group, coin_group, score_coin, platform_group)[source]¶

Reloads the level when the player is defeated

Input: accepts a group of sprites associated with the world

Args:

level(int):

player(pygame.sprite.Group()):

blob_group(pygame.sprite.Group()):

lava_group(pygame.sprite.Group()):

exit_group(pygame.sprite.Group()):

coin_group(pygame.sprite.Group():

score_coin(pygame.sprite.Group()):

platform_group(pygame.sprite.Group()):

Returns:

world (World): instance of the class World with reseted level
